## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 288, 905, 303]]<|/det|>
0606/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 313, 153, 328]]<|/det|>
Paper 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 313, 905, 328]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 338, 905, 352]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 365, 395, 381]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 395, 359, 411]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 431, 222, 446]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 448, 880, 617]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 645, 212, 660]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 662, 728, 694]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 91, 615, 108]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 152, 576, 170]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 183, 255, 201]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 213, 400, 232]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 233, 596, 268]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 290, 243, 308]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 310, 767, 348]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[131, 364, 512, 401]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 428, 401, 447]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 453, 549, 483]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\{2a + (n - 1)d\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 505, 343, 523]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 528, 443, 598]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 630, 611, 648]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 661, 171, 679]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 689, 598, 740]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \sec^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 785, 256, 803]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 812, 608, 850]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[418, 846, 610, 866]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 873, 571, 902]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[89, 82, 102, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 92, 871, 381]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 920, 427]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = a \sin bx + c\) for \(- 360^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 360^{\circ}\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are constants. Find the values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 408, 920, 427]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 599, 94, 617]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 539, 618]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\log_3 r + 2\log_9 s = 8\), find the value of \(r s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 599, 920, 617]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 94, 94, 112]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 616, 116]]<|/det|>
Given that \(y = \tan \frac{x}{2}\), find the exact value of \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) when \(x = \frac{\pi}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 95, 918, 113]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 82, 92, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 81, 764, 102]]<|/det|>
A team of 8 people is to be formed from 6 teachers, 5 doctors and 4 police officers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 114, 144, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 114, 512, 133]]<|/det|>
Find the number of teams that can be formed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 115, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 225, 146, 243]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 225, 678, 243]]<|/det|>
Find the number of teams that can be formed without any teachers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 225, 920, 243]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 335, 144, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 335, 863, 354]]<|/det|>
Find the number of teams that can be formed with the same number of doctors as teachers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 336, 920, 355]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 94, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 586, 101]]<|/det|>
DO NOT USE A CALCULATOR IN THIS QUESTION.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 114, 479, 131]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 139, 816, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 336, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the trapezium \(ABCD\). The lengths of \(AB\), \(BC\) and \(CD\) are \(8\sqrt{7} - 7\), \(\sqrt{7} + 2\) and \(9\sqrt{7} - 9\) respectively. The line \(BC\) is perpendicular to the lines \(AB\) and \(CD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 383, 144, 401]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 383, 754, 401]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the trapezium, giving your answer in its simplest form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 384, 920, 402]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 740, 146, 758]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 740, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the trapezium, giving your answer in the form \(p\sqrt{7} +q\), where \(p\) and \(q\) are rational numbers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 755, 920, 774]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 501, 144, 518]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 500, 920, 535]]<|/det|>
Find \(\cot DBC\) , giving your answer in the form \(r\sqrt{7} +s\) , where \(r\) and \(s\) are simplified rational numbers.  [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 82, 92, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 82, 662, 101]]<|/det|>
In this question, all lengths are in metres and all angles are in radians.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 109, 688, 365]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 377, 920, 413]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle with centre \(O\) and radius 5. The points \(A, B, C\) and \(D\) lie on the circumference of the circle. Angle \(DOC = \theta\). Angle \(AOD =\) angle \(COB = 0.5\). The length of the minor arc \(DC\) is 3.75.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 425, 144, 444]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 316, 444]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\theta = 0.75\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 426, 918, 444]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 586, 146, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 586, 470, 604]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 143, 503]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 485, 428, 504]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 485, 920, 504]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 87, 97, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 87, 144, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 87, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
The line \(y = 3x - 2\) intersects the curve \(2x^{2} - xy + y^{2} = 2\) at the points \(A\) and \(B\). The point \(C\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 108, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
with coordinates \(\left(k, \frac{7}{8}\right)\) lies on the perpendicular bisector of the line \(AB\). Find the exact value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 485, 146, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 485, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
The point \(D\) lies on the perpendicular bisector of \(AB\) such that \(D\) is a reflection of \(C\) in the line \(AB\). Find the coordinates of \(D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 920, 517]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 101, 94, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 97, 420, 123]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \frac{(3x^2 - 5)^{\frac{1}{3}}}{x + 4}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 128, 143, 149]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 128, 900, 170]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\) can be written in the form \(\frac{Ax^2 + Bx + C}{(3x^2 - 5)\frac{2}{3}(x + 4)^2}\) , where \(A, B\) and \(C\) are integers. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[925, 144, 937, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 81, 94, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 81, 650, 101]]<|/det|>
In this question, all distances are in metres and time, \(t\), is in seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 655, 139]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) moves with a speed of 14.5 parallel to the vector \(\left(- \frac{20}{21}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 145, 143, 164]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 144, 386, 165]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity vector of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 145, 920, 164]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 256, 391, 285]]<|/det|>
Initially, \(P\) has position vector \(\binom{3}{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 293, 144, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 293, 512, 312]]<|/det|>
Write down the position vector of \(P\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 293, 920, 312]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 643, 411]]<|/det|>
A second particle \(Q\) has position vector \(\left(- \frac{1}{3}\right) + \left(- \frac{5}{7.5}\right)t\) at time \(t\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 416, 143, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 416, 789, 435]]<|/det|>
Find, in terms of \(t\), the distance between \(P\) and \(Q\) at time \(t\). Simplify your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 416, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 705, 148, 724]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 705, 467, 724]]<|/det|>
Hence show that \(P\) and \(Q\) never collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 705, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 83, 106, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 83, 153, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 82, 774, 102]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms of an arithmetic progression are \(3 \sin 2x\), \(5 \sin 2x\), \(7 \sin 2x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 114, 181, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 114, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
Show that the sum to \(n\) terms of this arithmetic progression can be written in the form \(n(n + a)\sin 2x\), where \(a\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 128, 920, 147]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 504, 180, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 496, 662, 525]]<|/det|>
Given that \(x = \frac{2\pi}{3}\), find the exact sum of the first 20 terms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 502, 920, 521]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 87, 146, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 84, 730, 107]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms of a geometric progression are \(\ln 2y\), \(\ln 4y^2\), \(\ln 16y^4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 181, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 116, 569, 137]]<|/det|>
Find the \(n\)th term of this geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 119, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 228, 181, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 227, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
Find the sum to \(n\) terms of this geometric progression, giving your answer in its simplest form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 244, 920, 262]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 457, 143, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 881, 480]]<|/det|>
The first 3 terms of a different geometric progression are \(\left(2w - \frac{1}{4}\right)\), \(\left(2w - \frac{1}{4}\right)^2\), \(\left(2w - \frac{1}{4}\right)^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 484, 774, 505]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(w\) for which this geometric progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 486, 920, 505]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
